issues.title: Add reference to architecture draft
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body:
Add a reference to the blockchain interoperability architecture draft.

Raised by Martin Gfeller <mgf=40acm.org@dmarc.ietf.org>

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Thank you Martin. This was also pointed out by Paul Hoffman at the last IETF meeting. 

The satp-core-07 draft now tells the reader to review first the SATP-Architecture draft.

issues.title: Refine Client application definition
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body:
Refine Client application definition.

Martin Gfeller <mgf=40acm.org@dmarc.ietf.org> said "Do we need to say what we want to achieve with the application? Simply interacting could mean anything. As the introduction mentions only gateways, this is the first time "application" is used."

We should make it clearer that the client application implements the end-user business logic (that requires interoperability) and interacts with a gateway via API1.

comments.author: RafaelAPB
comments.body: Migrated to the responsible draft repo https://github.com/ietf-satp/draft-augusto-api1/issues/1

comments.author: RafaelAPB
comments.body: Migrated to the responsible draft repo https://github.com/ietf-satp/draft-augusto-api1/issues/1

issues.title: Problems raised by Martin G.
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body:
Fix grammar/typos/references:

---
    Claim Type:

        Stipulates that JWT above is just one option. Perhaps always have "X type" before "X";
         i.e., "claim type" before "claim"
--- 
    Network:
        Might be worthwhile to define network.

---
    When do we speak about SAT and when about SATP?
   
        I think the model is for the protocol, so SATP Model, not SAT Model.
   
    local gateway
   
        "local" is understandable, but not actually defined. As the application is defined 
         to interact with a gateway, a gateway is always "local" from the perspective of
        the application.
       4.2 SAT Model

    When do we speak about SAT and when about SATP?
   
        I think the model is for the protocol, so SATP Model, not SAT Model.
   
    local gateway
   
        "local" is understandable, but not actually defined. As the application is defined 
         to interact with a gateway, a gateway is always "local" from the perspective of
        the application.

 ---

4.7.2 Message Type

    Inconsistent style - drop the  "This is the "
   
4.7.3 Digital Asset Identifier

    unique identifier (UUIDv2) that uniquely identifies
   
        unique, more unique, most unique? :-)
   
    application of the beneficiary
   
        This is the first time the application in NW2 is mentioned in an active role - in 
        the document above this point, I understood that while the NW2 and GW2 are involved,
        the application of the beneficiary is not actively involved.
       
4.7.4 Session ID: (delete the ":")

        Was the Context-Id introduced? Yes, but below. Somewhat circular. Same problem
        noted in Architecture document.
   
4.7.5 Transfer-Context ID

        Is the "Sequence Number" part of the Transfer-Context ID, or a possible implementation,
        or something additional?

4.7.8.  Payload Hash

        Is the algo to be used intentionally left open?
   

4.8  Negotiation of Security Protocols and Parameters

    transfer initiation stage (Stage-0)
   
        Isn't that Stage-1, according to 4.4?
       
7-9: Stages

    Do we need to repeat the use of HTTP GET and POST - until the parenthetical remark 
    about the TLS nonce for each Stage?
   
10.2

        The purpose The purpose
   
    Repeated.
   
17.2 Informative References

    Wouldn't including references to the SATP Architecture and Use Cases documents be good?

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: Thanks Martin. These are text editorial questions that we are updating the SATP-core drafts.

issues.title: Problems raised by Denis A.
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body: I believe UUIDv2 is too restrictive. I would suggest we mention a more technology-neutral formulation, e.g. that digital asset identifiers should be globally unique and let the implementors decide how the digital asset identifiers could be defined

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
The digital asset identifier structure is being addressed in the asset profile draft (not here in SATP-core). 

FYI. The identifier structure being discussed needs to be a JSON structure (i.e. not just a UUIDv2 string).

issues.title: Potential solution to fix whitespace trailing problems on PRs
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body:
By [Carsten Bormann <cabo@tzi.org>](mailto:cabo@tzi.org), via mailing list:

> However, note that EditorConfig also acts upon the yaml definition at the beginning of the draft,

I don’t know why this happens (would need to look at the editorconfig setup), but you probably don’t need a

pi:

subtree in the YAML any more.

Just replace that (and the “stand_alone: yes”) by

v: 3

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: This is a Editor tool problem.

issues.title: Problems raised by John Robotham
issues.author: RafaelAPB
issues.body: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/sat/uRr_-tBl0BxykY40DqmMzs2Ilfg/

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: The big issue was the use of the Transfer Proposal Reject message.  This has now been renamed into a generic "reject" message that will carry the Error_code/reason_code listed in the Appendix.

issues.title: Transfer-Context ID format?
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body:
Section 5.3.5 defines the transfer context ID, but only specifies that it "may be a complex data structure".   It fails to specify what format this might appear as in message(s).  Should it be encoded as a string?  Should it be encoded as a json sub-structure/obect?  Either?  Who needs to understand the format?  Just the side that defines it?  Who should define it?

The format may be outside the scope, but it still needs to specify how it should be encoded.

issues.title: Gateway Credential Type needs a list of values
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: Right now the credential type is under specified.  It merely gives an example.  For this specification to be usable it needs a specific type list.  It can come from somewhere else (see what I proposed in #30 for JWEB algorithms), or can be a list of acceptable values defined in the document and specified later (see #30 and the change to networkLockType).

issues.title: digitalAssetId format
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: The asset ID example shows that it's a UUID format, but I suspect it can be anything as long as its a string of some kind.  But if that's true, it should say so or otherwise state it's a UUID or something.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
The text has been updated to state the following:

"digitalAssetId REQUIRED: This is the globally unique identifier for the digital asset located in the origin network. The default format is JSON, with base64 encoding."

issues.title: originator and beneficiary public key specification types needed
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: The originatorPubkey and beneficiaryPubkey types don't specify what type of key should be in the field.  It's possible that a format/type field may be needed if you expect to have different format types, or if it's a single type then it should say what type.  Note that a single type is not likely acceptable due to not being forward modifiable, which is always a danger with cryptographic mechanisms eventually being broken.  If a format is picked (or range of formats) the list needs to be clearly defined (probably with a reference like I suggested for other values in #30).

issues.title: senderGatewaynetworkId and recipientGatewayNetworkId formats
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: these two fields don't explain what types of values are acceptable, and who defines them.  The examples look like integers but I suspect they could be defined by the network in question as any sort of selection string?

issues.title: networkLockTypes need defining
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: I proposed some value clean ups in #30 but the three types still need a definition of what they mean.  Right now they're simply three strings without any definition of what the types mean.

issues.title: Clarification for gatewayAccessControlProfile
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: I suggested some changes to this in #30 but the last sentence ("Default is only the gateway that created the logs can access them") didn't make any sense to me so I couldn't figure if what I added got in the way of it or how I could make it more understandable.

issues.title: gatewayCredentialProfile types needed
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: Similar to the other bugs, this definition can't be an undefined list of values and needs to be pointed at definitions of a particular set of types where both sides understands what a string will mean.

issues.title: transfer protocol message's transferContextId
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: It should be stated which party creates this value and whether or not both sides need to understand it or whether it's just a reference that one side needs to understand.

issues.title: transferInitClaimFormat
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: This (and other similar) values needs to be defined as to acceptable values.  The examples uses "TRANSFER_INIT_CLAIM_FORMAT_1" as a value, but that is not defined anywhere.  That may be the only acceptable value for this version of the specification?

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
The _CLAIM_FORMAT_1 value is used to denote the default format JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. 

The relevant parts of the draft have been updated as follows:

transferInitClaimFormat REQUIRED: The default format is JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. The default format is denoted as "TRANSFER_INIT_CLAIM_FORMAT_1".

lockAssertionClaimFormat REQUIRED. The default format is JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. The default format is denoted as "LOCK_ASSERTION_CLAIM_FORMAT_1".

mintAssertionFormat REQUIRED. The default format is JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. The default format is denoted as "MINT_ASSERTION_CLAIM_FORMAT_1".

burnAssertionClaimFormat REQUIRED. The default format is JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. The default format is denoted as "BURN_ASSERTION_CLAIM_FORMAT_1".

assignmentAssertionClaimFormat REQUIRED. The default format is JSON, with parts being base64 encoded as needed. The default format is denoted as "ASSIGNMENT_ASSERTION_CLAIM_FORMAT_1".

issues.title: message signature formats
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: The content response message (and others) specify that messages should be signed.  Signed how though?  I'd suggest stating that signed messages should use the format defined by the JOSE work.  RFC7515 eg?

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Section 5.2 currently states that:

"All SATP messages exchanged between gateways must be signed, using JSON Web Signatures mechanism (RFC7515)."

Do we need to get the sender gateway to actually choose with signature algorithm from those supported in RFC7515?

issues.title: lockAssertianClaimFormat is missing acceptable values and definitions
issues.author: hardaker

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Text has been updated to state the following:

lockAssertionClaimFormat REQUIRED. This is the format of the claim payoad. The default format of the claim is the JSON format [RFC8259], with the relevant payloads Base64 encoded.

issues.title: hashPrevMessage hash type?
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: The hashPrevMessage field doesn't indicate which hash type should be used.  And it probably needs a format type in order to allow for multiple hashing types.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: Actually, I think we want to re-use the JWK/JWS supported format types.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Text has been corrected throughout.  It now says:

hashPrevMessage REQUIRED. The cryptographic hash of the last message. The default hash algorithm is SHA256.

issues.title: Commitment prepration error handling
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: Section 10 has a sentence that says the stage must be completed within the time specfied (...) but it doesn't specify what happens when this fails to happen in time.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
The sentence has been clarified.  Now it reads as follows (start of Stage 3): 

This stage must be completed within the time specified
in the lockAssertionExpiration value in the lock-assertion message.
This value is the time when the lock or escrow upon the asset will expire on the origin network.

The completion of this stage is denoted by the signed Commit-Final Acknowledgement Receipt Message
sent from the receiver gateway (server) to the sender gateway (client).

If the lockAssertionExpiration timer at the client expires before the Commit-Final Acknowledgement Receipt Message
is received by the client, the client may terminate the session.

issues.title: Referecing the satp-gateway-recovery draft will hold publicatino
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: As is the reference to an ID in section 11 will make the publication hold for that other document to be completed.  Instead it could specify that crash recovery will be defined later, but still reference that draft as a informative reference.

issues.title: session resumption rollback
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: The 5th paragraph in section 11 talks about "until that stage" but "that" in the sentence is not very well defined.

issues.title: Recovery messages are half defined but also declared out of scope
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: I'd suggest simply sticking with the fact that they'll be defined in the future and not quoting them in the document at all since it's likely theyl'l change in the future as the other specification advances?

comments.author: RafaelAPB
comments.body: @hardaker yes, perhaps we should entirely remove references to it, and state we have a draft on crash recovery

issues.title: connection errors not specified
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body: It's unclear how to implement section 12.2 about connection errors.  The bad certificate error references a number of TLS sub-errors, but it's unclear what to do when errors occur.  Since they're connection errors, I assume that the connection should just be aborted since there is no way to send an error message?

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: Yes, any connection errors should result in the abort of the session.  From the 3PC message flow perspective, a connection error/loss is the same as a message in the flow being lost.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: 2nd set of fixes.

pulls.title: API1 Review
pulls.author: alexchiriac
pulls.body:
- change specific API1 protocol back to HTTP
- propose OAuth2.0 as the authentication mechanism for API1 clients
- clarify examples

After merging this PR, I will add a section for Considerations on Smart Contract Networks. In that section, I will mention that a smart contract to represent the asset on the destination network needs to be deployed before the client application starts an asset transfer.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: (from Alex)

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: We will consider this contribution for future discussions.

reviews.author: RafaelAPB
reviews.body: Anthony, thank you for your contribution. While there are some good ideas and suggestions (namely the introduction of a proof manifesto and payload), there are some concerns that need to be addressed prior to merging. See my comments below.

comments.body: This is not correct; SATP implements a variant of 2PC

typo on "cliam". I tend to agree with this more general description, but at the same time, I am reluctant of allowing the developer to implement ANY type of bridge. This has to be discussed within the group.
This is not correct; SATP ensures those properties
This is not correct; SATP ensures those properties
This is not correct; SATP ensures those properties
This seems reasonable, but it seems to me this is stage 0, which is currently out of scope. This has to be discussed within the group
See comments above
See comments above
This section is not necessary, as those parties are identified in the glossary (first part of the spec)
We do not have the notion of Sending network actor. These terms are subsumed by the notion of "gateway client", which is the gateway application responsible for managing the "actors"
There are new terms introduced here. If the group agrees to include them, they need to be introduced in the glossary.
See comments above
I think this is a good idea; we (should) include the type of proof along with the proof payload as part of the receipt
I don't understand the need for this parameter

Agree. 

The gateway is the term that the WG uses for the construct containing endpoint that is the execution point for 2PC flows with liveliness.

The term “facilitates” means something behind the gateway is the execution point of the 2PC.  But this is just wordsmithing and pushing the problem back to some other construct

The SATP protocol must cover the scenarios where the networks are closed/private.  The signed claims is techno-legal mechanism to ensure that the gateways are performing burning/minting, without any way of verifying if that has been done (because the ledgers are closed/private).

This is akin to a distributed database, where the main coordinator database deletes a record XYZ and then sends a message (claim) to the other N remote databases to delete (create) a record whose recordID is XYZ.

There no way that the coordinator database can see into the other N remote databases (to see if all of them have been honest and have performed the task. Its only later when there is inconsistencies across these databases that the issue will be detected.
Agree with Rafael.
Agree with Rafael.
Agree with Rafael. The point of SATP is is that it is the endpoint that must implement ACID.

The notion of “settlement finality indicator” is out of scope for SATP.  I think this is part of the context establishment in Stage 0 between the user applications App1 and App2. The users are assumed to already have a legal agreement to engage with each other and transfer assets.

SATP is a simple unidirectional transfer protocol that implements 2PC. It is not an entire settlement finality mechanism, which may include other networks that deal with payments (e.g. the Delivery-versus-Payment use cases).

@Agree with Rafael.  For the 2PC commitment flows, the gateway is the actor.  The Originator could be viewed as a sending-actor that may utilize other actors (e.g. escrow entities), but that is out of scope for SATP.

This is an overkill in wordsmithing.  The term Originator and Beneficiary is already defined in FATF Recommendation No16.  We do not want to invent our own terms.

Using 4 words (e.g. Receiving Network Beneficial Owner) just to say “Beneficiary” (who is assumed to be in NW2 ) is much simpler.
This set of task are part of Stage-0, so it is out of scope for Core.
Identities and identity verification is Stage-0 (i.e. out of scope).

In draft core-04 the set of items that is assumed to be gained from Stage-0 is listed in Section 7.1 (Transfer Initialization Claims). 

The Stage-1 Commence message carries a hash of these agreed claims:
hash_transfer_init_claims REQUIRED: Hash of the Transfer Initialization Claims in the Transfer Proposal message.
Thanks Anthony. Good point - we need a verified ID.
I think the settlement_finality requirement needs to be communicated in Stage-0.  This is because SATP-Core only runs between the endpoints at the gateways.  It cannot "see" beyond the 2PC flow.

pulls.title: Misc chair proposed fixes
pulls.author: hardaker
pulls.body: This PR contains a LOT of misc fixes and suggested changes to make the specification more complete.  Please review the changes carefully before you decide whether you should merge it or not.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: Merging comments.
lgtm

We mention "unless otherwise noted", but I don't believe we actually do note otherwise. Would it be fair to remove the statements? I had a look at all the message examples and I don't believe there is any base64 encoding. Unless maybe somebody can point to a specific example that I may have missed?
In addition, there are two spaces between `JSON Strings.`  and `Values`
2 spaces between `specification.` and `Implementations`. Apologies if these are intentional, going ahead with the review, I will note when I notice there are 2 spaces.
lgtm

I believe that in some of the earlier feedback, we mentioned we want to discourage the use of vague "etc." statements in enumerations. Unless, perhaps, the enumeration here actually warrants it? I would propose we remove the enumeration and rely on a specific example instead.
lgtm

2 spaces between `gateway.` and `Each`.
typo, missing "be" in `either an Algorithm`

otherwise lgtm
lgtm
typo, believe we mean "receiver" instead of `received`

Good catch! I'm not sure if you've raised this in the issues yet (will finish the review first then look at the issues), but the error messages should have at least an example and be in a consistent JSON format as well, I believe. Ideally they should also be accompanied by an HTTP status. The good news is that the hard work of actually wording out the error messages has been done by the other authors 🙌

2 spaces between `network.` and `The`. This segment should also be in line with the one above. I just noticed many of the bullet point list items are arbitrarily split on separate rows. Could I perhaps fix that as a commit to your branch?

lgtm about the format description though
2 spaces between `gateways.` and `Some`
2 spaces between `"HASH_TIME_LOCK".` and `Future`
lgtm
lgtm
I think there is a typo here, a missing "is" or "it" changed to "is" in  `as that it implementation`

reviews.author: alexchiriac
reviews.body:
Left a few comments, happy to discuss on error examples and base64 encoding!

Fantastic contribution, thank you so much, Wes! Mostly looking good to me!

comments.author: RafaelAPB
comments.body: @VRamakrishna I have incorporated your suggestions. Thank you for the review.
The `README.md` already provides an instruction to build the repo using `make`, so I wonder whether the Makefile-related instructions here would be more appropriate in that file.

I believe the default `Makefile` (from the `i-d-template` repo) already provides a `fix-lint` target for this (see https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/main/main.mk#L237), so I'm not sure if this is needed here.
That's true. It is probably not needed. I'll enhance the docs.
Agreed, and see comment below.

reviews.author: VRamakrishna
reviews.body: LGTM. Thanks for addressing my comments.
